contextId.information: This is probably an exaggeration meaning that she spent so much time in the temple that it seemed as though she never left it. AT: "was always at the temple" or "was often at the temple" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
"nowhere to rest my head" or "nowhere to sleep." Jesus is exaggerating in order to get across the point that he was not welcome anywhere to live. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
This is an exaggeration in order to express how many people there were. AT: "they were stepping on each other" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])

Possible meanings are 1) this is a hyperbole for the master dealing out harsh punishment toward the slave, or 2) this describes the manner in which the servant will be executed and buried as punishment. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
contextId.quote: cut him in pieces and appoint a place for him with the unfaithful

contextId.information: This is an exaggeration to make a point. AT: "a very large shrub" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])

Here, "hate" is an exaggeration to show how important it is to love Jesus much more than anyone else. AT: "If anyone comes to me and does not love me more than he loves his father ... he cannot be my disciple" or "Only if a person loves me more than he loves his own father ... can he be my disciple" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublenegatives]])
contextId.quote: If anyone comes to me and does not hate his own father ... he cannot be my disciple

contextId.information: This is an exaggeration to stress that there were very many of them. AT: "many tax collectors" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])

This does not mean that God is not pleased with those who obey himâ€”he takes great delight in them. But the joy in heaven at the moment when a person is saved from their sin is an even greater joy! (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
contextId.quote: more than over ninety-nine righteous persons who do not need to repent

contextId.information: "wasted all your wealth on prostitutes" or "thrown away all your money by paying prostitutes." Possible meanings are 1) he assumed this is how his brother spent the money or 2) he is using hyperbole to intentionally exaggerate his brother's sin. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])

This is an exaggeration to express that they did not do anything worthy of praise. AT: "We are ordinary slaves" or "We servants do not deserve your praise" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])

It is impossible for a camel to fit through the eye of a needle. Therefore, it appears that Jesus may have been using hyperbole to mean it is extremely difficult for a rich man to enter God's kingdom. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
contextId.quote: a camel to go through a needle's eye

contextId.information: "They will not leave any of the stones in place." This is a hyperbole to express how completely the enemies would destroy the city which was built of stones. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
contextId.quote: They will not leave one stone upon another

contextId.information: This does not mean she put in as much money as the rich men. Rather, it means that God considered her gift to be more significant that the larger sums the men gave. AT: "the small gift of this widow was more valuable than larger gifts of the rich men" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
contextId.quote: this poor widow put in more than all of them

contextId.information: This is an exaggeration to emphasize the seriousness of the persecution. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
contextId.quote: You will be hated by everyone

contextId.information: This is an exaggeration to emphasize the size of the crowd. AT: "A very large number of people" or "Almost everyone" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])

"do not cry about my situation." Jesus did not mean that they should stop weeping for him. He is using hyperbole to say that they had even more reason to weep for their own situation. AT: "you are weeping for me, but even worse things are going to happen to you, so" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
contextId.quote: do not weep for me, but

contextId.information: "They strongly urged him." The Greek word means to use physical force over an extended time, but it seems to be hyperbole. It took them some time and effort to persuade him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
This is an exaggeration to express that they went into the temple courtyard every day. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
